sect1.title: Browsing the web with Mozilla
sect1.para: Mozilla Firefox is one of the most popular GNU/Linux browsers, and is rapidly gaining market share on the Windows platform. Many browsers are based on the same rendering engine that Firefox uses(Gecko), for example Epiphany and Galeon. This section is a short introduction to Mozilla Firefox, and provides some hints that might be helpful.

Libranet includes Firefox, and it can be installed via the conventional Libranet package management tools. Firefox can be started by launching Apps/Net/Mozilla Firefox. The default Libranet graphical environment also includes a Firefox launcher in the main menu.

sect2.title: Plugins
sect2.para:
Some sites require plugins like Flash or Java. Realplayer, Flash, Java and the MozPlugger plugins can be installed via from the Libranet archive or CDs as the following packages:
realplayer macromedia-flashplayer sun-j2re1.5 mozplugger

sect2.title: Tabs
sect2.para: Firefox provides tabs, which means you do not have to open a new window if you want to visit several sites simultaneously. You can just create multiple tabs within one window, which have different active sites. Try pressing the <Ctrl> + <t> keys, as you can see a new tab is opened in which you can start browsing. You can browse through the tags with the <Ctrl> + <Page Up> and <Ctrl> + <Page Down> keys. You can also open a link in a new tab by clicking on the link with the right mouse button and selecting Open Link in New Tab.

sect2.title: Popup blocking
sect2.para: Many Internet sites display popup ads, which can become a bit annoying, fortunately Firefox has a function that blocks popup windows. This option can be found in the preferences window, which is accessible from the Edit menu. The popup window settings are located under the Web features section. By default the Block Popup Windows option is enabled. You can allow popups for specific sites after clicking the Allowed sites button.

sect1.title: Mozilla Thunderbird
sect1.para: Mozilla Thunderbird is the e-mail client that is developed by the Mozilla project. Together with Firefox, Thunderbird offers an excellent Internet application suite. Thunderbird features:

listitem.para: An addressbook with LDAP support, which allows detailed configuration of contacts.
Support for SSL/TSL message encryption and/or signing, and support of GnuPG through the Enigmail extension.
An extension architecture that will let you expand the functionality of Thunderbird easily.

sect2.title: Setting up e-mail accounts
sect2.para: The next thing you will probably want to do is to setup some E-Mail accounts. The first time Thunderbird is started it will ask the user to setup an account, so there is a good change that you have already set up an E-Mail account. The account settings window is available available through the Edit -> Properties menu item. In the account settings window you can add, edit and remove accounts.

Click the "Add Account" button to add an e-mail account. This will launch an assistant that will help you setting up an account. Thunderbird will first ask you what kind of account you would like to set up. Select Email account, and click on the Next button.

The first step of setting up an e-mail account is filling in some identity information. You can fill your name in the Your Name input field, and the E-Mail address that is used for this account in the Email Address field.

The next step is to choose what kind of E-Mail server you will be using. Most provides provide both POP and IMAP access to e-mail accounts. POP is an older protocol that downloads all messages from the e-mail server. IMAP leaves the messages on the server, and downloads the messages when that is demanded (e.g. when a message is selected from the message list). But in any case IMAP will keep the messages on the server. If you have a dial-up connection, it is usually best to use POP to avoid having to stay online to read e-mail, if you read e-mail from many different locations IMAP is the obvious protocol choice. With both protocols you will have to fill in the name of the e-mail server in the Incoming Server input field. After you have chosen a protocol and filled in the server name, you can click on Next to continue the configuration. The next step is still closely related to the previous step - Thunderbird will ask you to fill in the user name for the incoming server. Fill in this user name in the Incoming User Name field, and click the Next button.

Finally, Thunderbird will ask you to give a name for the account you have just set up. You can fill in this name, and click on Next to finish the configuration. Thunderbird will show the account settings you have just made. You can confirm these settings with the Finish button.

If this is the first account that you are setting up, Thunderbird will also ask you to specify a server and username for outgoing mail. This is the SMTP server that is provided by your ISP or E-Mail provider.

sect1.title: GAIM, the universal instant messenger
sect1.para: GAIM is one of those killer applications. Once you got used to it changes are you never want to look back at other messengers. GAIM supports AIM, ICQ, MSN Messenger, Yahoo, IRC, Jabber, Gadu-Gadu and Zephyr. The nice thing about GAIM is that you can use these services simultaneously.

sect2.title: Some first advice
sect2.para: There have been many problems in the past with supporting all messengers, because many messaging protocols are closed. The Jabber protocol is a big exception; it is an open protocol that is an official standard. The Jabber user-base is quite large and surpassed ICQ in user numbers. There are many Jabber clients available, for most commonly used platforms. Try to convince yourself and friends to switch to Jabber. More information about Jabber can be found at:

sect2.title: Configuring accounts
sect2.para: When you launch GAIM for the first time you can setup accounts using the accounts button. After you have installed GAIM you can setup accounts with the Tools -> Accounts menu item. This will present a window with the accounts that are currently configured. You can use the Online check-box next to an account name to go online or off-line. If the Auto-login check-box is checked GAIM will automatically log in the next time GAIM is launched. Adding, modifying or deleting accounts is easy with the buttons on the bottom side of the window. Adding an account should be fairly straightforward, make sure you select the right protocol.

If GAIM does not work (well) with a supported protocol, you should probably update your GAIM version. It often happens that the protocols are changed slightly, which breaks third party clients like GAIM.
